Thank you!

text:
I’m having trouble getting a pile of urls re-crawled from Google Search Console. We pushed a bad site update that marked our blog as “no-index” :skull: Most of the traffic has recovered but I still have ~50 urls that Google hasn’t crawled since submitting a manual request for re-indexing per page and also trying a full verification of the fix (been waiting since March 1st!).

Anyone have any tips?

elements.text: I’m having trouble getting a pile of urls re-crawled from Google Search Console. We pushed a bad site update that marked our blog as “no-index”

Most of the traffic has recovered but I still have ~50 urls that Google hasn’t crawled since submitting a manual request for re-indexing per page and also trying a full verification of the fix (been waiting since March 1st!).

Anyone have any tips?

text:
writing the brief version:
1. make sure these pages have enough internal links
2. create an XML sitemap specifically for these URLs, and submit it to GSC. Good signal for G to recrawl and reindex, and you can easily track its progress.

elements.text: writing the brief version:

create an XML sitemap specifically for these URLs, and submit it to GSC. Good signal for G to recrawl and reindex, and you can easily track its progress.

text: :hugging_face::heartbeat::writing_hand:Hello lovely Super Path community! I’ve been noodling over this question for a month now and I’m hoping to get your insight. I’m looking to bring on content support on my team and I’m not sure exactly what to call the role- content manager, copywriter, content specialist? The person will create many different forms of content based on briefs and requests (email copy for nurture and sales cadences, landing page copy, social copy, product—focused enablement material, ad copy, etc.), copy edit/be the last set of eyes before publication for marketing projects, and also handle some operational marketing tasks like formatting, scheduling, etc. What title do you think best encompasses these tasks? For reference, this is B2B.

elements.text: Hello lovely Super Path community! I’ve been noodling over this question for a month now and I’m hoping to get your insight. The person will create many different forms of content based on briefs and requests (email copy for nurture and sales cadences, landing page copy, social copy, product—focused enablement material, ad copy, etc.), copy edit/be the last set of eyes before publication for marketing projects, and also handle some operational marketing tasks like formatting, scheduling, etc. What title do you think best encompasses these tasks? For reference, this is B2B.

elements.text: Anybody have experience in PR or know good resources for adding PR to client projects? Working on a proposal for a prospect who's interested in getting into online magazines like Wired, etc.

text: I did a variety of this last year and I was brought on as a marketing coordinator and content writer. I will say doing that amount of different kinds of content and tasks will inevitably burn out your employee. I was able to shed some of my random duties over time, and I am much happier at work with my new title of content and social media manager. I understand that B2B companies have to often be scrappy, but you are essentially trying to hire for 3-5 roles in one person and that can’t be great for the long-term sanity of whoever you hire. So if you go through with this role, I’d keep an eye on whoever you hire to make sure that they learn great prioritization skills, and that they understand that sometimes some of their job duties will be on the back burner. They are only working 40 hours per week, after all.

text:
Hey y'all. I have a very specific question followed by a more general one :sweat_smile: Does anyone know who I could reach out to on the Animalz team regarding an editing position?

Here's the rub. It's part-time, contract. Is it overkill to want to reach out for these types of roles? Does it matter if the outreach is just to put yourself out there/connect versus making concrete inquiries into the position? My thought has been that, if you can manage it, it's better if your application isn't faceless. But I've never been on the other side of this equation. Maybe it's really annoying to deal with for low impact hires!

text:
It depends on what things they’ll be designing as a marketing designer. Is it all marketing-related design from brand to blogs to landing pages?—probably best to have them report to someone that is handling all those things

If it’s more specific to design that’s meant to support content, it might help to have them report to someone in content so they’re not thinking about any of the other stuff

elements.text:

i won't speak for animalz but i'd say it's good to reach out. most companies hiring for roles like this want people to formally apply too, but it's good to make the human connection too
